bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, September 6, 1889

div1.p: Carter comments on the quarantine service and his wife's health.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, September 6, 1889
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of U S Gulf Quarantine, Surgeon's Office,
Sept 6, 1889.
Dear Ma:
div1.p:
Another week of Quarantine is
gone. It isn't usual for any save a young
person to be glad over the flight of time;
but then it is not usual to be on Quar-
antine & so I am exempt by position
from the observation of ordinary rules.
I have a schooner from Havana - with a
foul bill (1 case) in now; but it is really
cold, blowing a norther & one needs a
blanket. Also a vessel on the bar - large
schooner - due to drunkeness. I am not
a prohibitionist, because I think it impracticable
but it is a vice with which I have
no patience. So far as I can judge,
it does more harm than all other
vices together, if it & the Love of Money
were banished mankind, 99/100, of the
suffering & wrong done one's neibor w'd
be out of it. This is moralising, but think
of a vessel putting to sea, with Pilot Cap-
tain, both mates & quartermaster, drunk-
really drunk - & the crews - “badly mixed”,
& losing that vessel in a hard norther>
on Chandeleur bar & any body will
moralize. If the wind changes ever so lit-
tle to the W. (it will hardly do it). She will
break up in 30 minutes.

I went over to Ship Island Quarantine
to see Dr. Champlin who was very ill, he's
wife wrote. He is the Q. physician for Miss.
I found the trouble less than she said,
but, as at all the state & county stations,
every thing in the hands of subordinates
trying to make money. He doesn't do it,
but he doesn't attend to the work
himself. This station is as far as I can
see the only safeguard of the gulf
between N. O. & Tampa. You know
all “infected” vessels are sent me from
some ports & all from “infected ports”
by others. So the vessels that are subjec-
ted to quarantine at local stations do
not require any any & therefore
C1
B22
the neglect is not dangerous. There
was nothing wrong about the ship as first.

My fall work of construction, except
putting in 6, chimneys, is pretty well
over & I am glad. You have no idea how
many different kinds of things one
has to know in places like this.
When the Q. raises I want to go to
Florida, long enough to see to my place.
If I stay in this place next summer,
I don't want to, Laura will go to Va: If
possible to board in the Mountains. I
was thinking that maybe the Randolphs
in Nelsen could take her. The trouble
trouble about Geddes & Belevet; is the
size of the houses & the in advisability
of mixing up business & kinfolks.
She would of course stay with you as N. R. some
but the size of the house would come in there too
I expect, & I want her to get to highland,
what do you think?

Give my love to all, Little E. seems
to keep well & is growing again,
but you are mistaken in thinking the other
two are good, they are not, wish they were
